title: 'I quit my job after boss told me my skirts were distracting boys from work'
text:

It's no secret that women are often told to hide or downplay their sexuality so as not to "distract" others.

Just this week it was reported that female employees at Ernst & Young, one of the world's top accounting firms, were told during a training session "not to flaunt bodies because sexuality scrambles the mind".

And now another woman has come forward to share her own story of being sexualised against her will in the workplace.

Australian sexpert Nadia Bokody has spoken out about the reason why she quit her job as a teacher at an all-boys high school and headed down a very different career path.

In an opinion piece for news.com.au, she recalled the moment she was summoned to see her boss for an "urgent" meeting.

Understandably she was worried about what offence she had committed to land her there, but she never expected him to come out with what he did.

"We need to talk about how you're dressed," he said. "We'd prefer if you didn't wear skirts or anything figure-hugging. It's distracting the boys from their work."

"Suddenly I feel less like one of the staff and more like one of the students," Bokody writes.

She goes on to explain that it was her first experience of being sexualised against her will - but it certainly wasn't the last.

Two days after the meeting, she handed in her resignation, not because she was uncomfortable (although she was), but because she believed the young men she'd been teaching were capable of more than admiring her outfits.

Despite the experience, she enjoys wearing sexy clothing but is still frequently told that if she wants to be taken seriously she needs to "cover up".

"The fact that I have multiple university degrees, manage a team and run my own successful company all seemingly count for nothing if my bra's visible on Instagram ," Bokody continues.

She goes on to call out the ideology and pop culture for reinforcing it and teaching us that "women exist to appeal to men".

"There's a danger to this kind of objectification," she adds. "It allows us to look the other way when women are slut-shamed, harassed and assaulted.

"It gives us permission to put the burden back onto the woman when she receives unsolicited sexual attention. To tell ourselves, she must have secretly wanted it."

Discover more about Nadia's journey with sex and body positivity over on Instagram.
description: A woman has revealed how being sexualised against her will caused her to resign from her job
